speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, over the past 10 days the world has heard incredibly good news about the Syrian-Jewish community.
On April 19 Syrian officials finally released the Swed brothers who had been in prison since 1987 without a fair trial. I was elated to hear the news that Selim and Eli Swed were released on Passover, a celebration of freedom for the Jewish people.
Then on Monday, April 27, there was welcome news that Syria will end travel and personal and real estate property restrictions on Jews.
As chairman of the Canadian Parliamentary Friendship Group for Syrian Jewry, I hope these developments signify the resolve of the Syrian government to end all discriminatory abuses of Syrian Jews.

Mr. Speaker, later today about two dozen busloads of constituents from my riding will be making a trip to Parliament Hill as an expression of support for a united Canada.
The idea for this rally originated with Diane Manion, a Brockville high school teacher, who, along with some of her colleagues and friends, decided to visit the seat of the nation's government.
This rally which started rather small has grown dramatically, illustrating that ordinary Canadians are concerned about Canada's future and are suggesting by their
trip to the Parliament Buildings that Canadians do indeed want to break the silence. They hope all other Canadian communities will express themselves in this or some similar way.
We should no longer take Canada for granted. The message is clear from my community. We are one united Canada.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to announce that the Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs is actively involved in a feasibility study on the development of a national data bank for use by poison control centres. A national data bank that would be available to provincial poison control centres would be an essential factor in consumer protection, especially where children are concerned.
When an accident occurs, poison control centres would be able to provide quick and specific advice to consumers and health professionals on what should be done and what kind of treatment should be given or where the victim could receive appropriate care.
I would also like to commend the Quebec Poison Control Centre for developing the TOXIN software. Users of the software will have rapid access to vast amounts of data on the composition of many different chemical products (drugs, pesticides and other toxic substances) that would be included in the Canadian data bank for poison control information. This work represents a major contribution to the health and safety of all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Employment and Immigration began his new live-in caregiver program on April 27 which continues a

April 29, 1992
medieval injustice requiring a foreign caregiver to live in the employer's home.
The government has failed to honour its promise of February 26 to give to the committee on labour, employment and immigration the studies he claims shows that Canada has no shortage of live-out caregivers.
I understand that the department officials gave the reports to the minister's office a few days after February 26. Nevertheless, two months later the minister is still withholding the evidence he claims justifies his live-in requirement.
The minister also began the program without publishing the controversial regulations for public comment and has often even refused my office a request for a copy of the regulation.
In fact his regulation does nothing at all to protect live-in caregivers from the kinds of abuse they have suffered, as he well knows.
I call on the minister to table both the departmental studies on this matter and the regulations today.

Mr. Speaker, potato producers in Prince Edward Island are concerned that this government is not being clear about possible compensation for their 1991 seed potato crop.
Due to this government's misdiagnosis last year where only 10 out of 96 cases were correctly diagnosed as PVYn positive, seed sales were lost for another year.
Yet there are mixed signals coming from Agriculture Canada about what type of compensation will be forthcoming.
Island farmers deserve better than to be kept in the dark on this issue.
Despite the knowledge that PVYn is not widespread in Prince Edward Island, despite the acceptance of the zoning plan put forward by the industry, Agriculture Canada, and the province, despite the fact there is no scientific justification for the ban, the blanket restrictions remain in place.
I urge the Minister of Agriculture to remove the atmosphere of uncertainty and immediately announce his plans to compensate Prince Edward Island potato producers for the 1991 crop.

Mr. Speaker, there were lots of headlines yesterday and questions in this House about a helicopter contract which went to a company in the province of Quebec.
It has been raised as a divisive issue suggesting somehow that Quebec is getting more than its fair share out of Confederation.
I would like to know where the headline writers were when the $1 billion military contract for new vehicles went to London, Ontario; where the headline writers were when the $1 billion contract for communications equipment went to Calgary and where were the headline writers when $4.5 billion went to New Brunswick for the frigate program? Where were the voices then?
Canada is not a balance sheet. But even if it were, the numbers would not look very bad these days. But I implore Canadians not to fall to this divisive rhetoric and stop looking at these contracts to Quebec as if they were different from any other part of the country.
We are proud of all the contracts let equally and fairly in all parts of this country.

Mr. Speaker, as I speak, two Canadians, Christine Lamont and David Spencer are languishing in a Brazilian jail.
The tragedy is that they could be released and they could be released now. All the Canadian minister of external affairs has to do is ask, but she has yielded to technical and bureaucratic arguments and refuses to do so.
I am particularly concerned that the Brazilian trial judge said he was under strong political pressure to convict all 10 accused.
April 29, 1992

Surely the role of the Canadian government is to put Canada first and help Canadians in trouble abroad. The Canadian government is all they have.
I ask the minister, in view of the strong reaction from my riding and from other parts of Canada to her decision, and the indication today that members from all parties on the justice committee want to re-examine the case, that she refer the facts to the justice committee and keep an open mind about asking for their release in the future.

Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Calgary Southwest) Mr. Speaker, congratulations to our women's hockey team on their medal-winning performance at the 1992 women's world hockey championships that were held in Finland.
In an exciting final game on Sunday, Canada beat the U.S. team eight to zero. This is Team Canada's second straight win at these championships which had its debut here in Ottawa in 1990. It makes them the only team to hold the world title in women's hockey to date.
I look forward to seeing women's hockey included in the Winter Olympics of 1998. Meanwhile, I am sure all parliamentarians and all Canadians join me in applauding the achievements of Team Canada's players and coaches, as well as wishing them all the best in the future.

Mr. Speaker, for some time a work conflict has existed between Nationair and several hundred flight attendants who have been without a regular pay cheque since November 1991.
I have spoken to the president of Nationair, Mr. Obadia, and to representatives of the union. It seems to me that they both want a fair settlement.
Nationair flight attendants are mainly female although there are some male workers. There is a great concern about having them return to work soon. A mediator was appointed. Recently, he presented his report to the Minister of Labour.
I urge the minister to do all he can to bring about an end to the present work difficulties at Nationair. If possible, I would request that he make the mediator's findings public.

Mr. Speaker, Ontario's NDP government cries foul while trying to blame its own wanton ineptness on Ottawa.
But audited accounts clearly prove the total dollar value of federal transfers to Queen's Park have increased every year since 1984. In fact, during this period average federal transfers to Ontario went up 6.1 per cent each year, while those to other provinces averaged only 5.5 per cent.
Meanwhile, Ontario government spending has shot up 10 per cent each year, while federally we have held such increases to about one-third of that at 3.9 per cent.
Two successive Ontario governments have been on a spending rampage, and tomorrow Ontario taxpayers will have to pay.

Mr. Speaker, the constitutional affairs minister indicated that we are making great progress on the building blocks of a constitutional agreement and that is good news.
But at the same time he expressed doubts and uncertainty over the prospect of real Senate reform and unfortunately, once again, refused to take a strong stand in favour of a truly elected, effective and more equal Senate.
Let there be no misunderstanding. There cannot be a fair and acceptable constitutional package without serious Senate reform.
The western and Atlantic regions are willing to compromise to keep this country united, but only if the same spirit of co-operation is shown by political leaders in other regions. The only way to have a new Canada is to have an effective second chamber representing the regions and holding the executive branch accountable.

April 29, 1992
Oral Questions
I urge the minister to make this kind of Senate reform an essential building block in a new constitutional agreement.

Mr. Speaker, it is a day for recognizing our champions.
This last weekend in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, the Lac St. Louis Lions won the title in the Air Canada Cup, a national midget hockey tournament and the Beacons-field Lady Bison girls volleyball team captured the silver medal in the eastern Canadian finals at Charlottetown.
I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate coach Blair Mackasey of the Lions as well as coach Steve Leighton of Beaconsfield for their volleyball team.
[Translation\
On behalf of all residents of the riding of Lachine- Lac-Saint-Louis, I warmly congratule the athletes on both teams, and I also want to say we are very proud to have them in the riding.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. For seven and a half years the Prime Minister has said that he is taking action to fight illiteracy. That is what he has told Canadians during two terms of office.
According to a report issued today by the Economic Council of Canada, more than one in four young people in Canada cannot even read a newspaper article and almost half cannot add up a restaurant bill.
The council goes on to say that if we pursue our current policies, the policies of his government, our schools could well produce over a million functionally illiterate people in the next 10 years. Does the Prime Minister realize we are sitting on an education time bomb? What has he done to diffuse it?

Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend probably knows Canada spends more per capita on education than any other industrialized country in the world with the exception of Sweden. One of the factors that entered into the United Nations assessment of Canada as the number one nation in the world in which to live last week reflected on that commitment, broadly speaking, to education.
As usual my hon. friend has been selective in her choice of analysis coming from the report because the report indicates Canada is second only to the United States of America in average years of schooling. There are no significant gender differences of any kind in educational levels which is most encouraging, given the kinds of problems we are trying to solve-it was mentioned on the floor of the House of Commons yesterday-and the report says that access to post-secondary studies in Canada is significantly higher than most other countries in the world.
I would think my hon. friend might be able to see a little ray of sunshine in some of the things that are going on in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I cannot find a ray of sunshine in the fact that almost half the young people in Canada cannot even add up a restaurant bill.

We know why the Prime Minister is winding up the Economic Council of Canada. He does not like being reminded that his policies are a total failure.
The Prime Minister can shut down the Economic Council, and he can try and muzzle his critics, but the fact remains that his policies are producing a generation of young people who do not know how to read and write. According to the Council, labour market adjustment programs are pitiful, training programs are pitiful, research and development is pitiful, and the same applies to the assistance given French schools outside Quebec. Every sector where the federal government has a role to play is a disaster area. Why, why, why?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am astonished that the Liberal Party of Canada should bring such a devastating indictment against the provinces which, after all, have jurisdiction over education in this country.
April 29, 1992

The hon. member will have to admit, and she should tell Canadians and this House, that the government has acted in partnership with the provinces to help address the shortcomings of our system for acquiring knowledge in this country.
In the last Speech from the Throne-perhaps the hon. member would care to refresh her memory-we introduced our Prosperity Initiative. Two distinguished Canadians, Ms. Marie-Josee Drouin of Quebec and Mr. McCambly head a group that, in consultation with all Canadians, is trying to meet the challenge of the next century: the acquisition of knowledge. I think it would be of interest of the hon. member for the Liberal Party to show some desire to co-operate with other Canadians instead of doing nothing and always pointing to the dark side of our country, because after all, we have a wonderful country. Read the report.

Mr. Speaker, the report says that Canadian young people are graduating from school without knowing how to read or write. That is what the report says.
The report also says that when you consider federal government initiatives; labour market adjustment program-poor; apprenticeship programs-poor; research and development-appalling; help for French schools outside Quebec-poor; the areas for which the federal government is responsible are a total failure.
I ask the Prime Minister this question. Instead of closing down the legitimate criticisms of the Economic Council of Canada, will he not open his government's approach to a real strategy to deal with the almost one million Canadians who may graduate without being able to read or write over the next 10 years?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Welcome to the real world. Mr. Speaker, these people should look at what is happening in this country. What is the prosperity initiative all about? We talk with individual Canadians all around the country and we ask them to be a part of the revamping of the education system. We have devoted resources and money to do it.
Oral Questions
Members opposite say that we are dismissing those areas where we could do better. It is not the truth, it is not a fact. The hon. member should come of age and see what is happening now and respect the fact of provincial power over education. Stop indicting our teachers and our schools. We are not doing that badly and we can do better-we acknowledge that-and we will do it with them.

Mr. Speaker, I have never heard so much nonsense as in the first two answers. The Economic Council's report clearly points to a national crisis. This nation cannot afford to have one million illiterate young people join our labour force by the year 2000. It is evident that this government's policy on illiteracy has been a total disaster.
Why has the government allowed this problem to reach such a dangerous level?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the hon. member talks about hearing nonsense, obviously he was at his caucus this morning.
The fact of the matter is that learning is a challenge that all Canadians face. We have to respect the jurisdiction of provincial governments over education.
All we can do at the federal level is be a partner with the provinces, with individual Canadians, with our dedicated teachers in trying to improve the situation.
Members opposite are picturing Canada as if it is a banana republic in terms of education. That is not what the report said. It said we can improve. We are intent on improving education but we are not dictating to the provinces or the people what to do, but working with them.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the same minister.
As you play your political football games with the provinces-
Oh, oh.
Please put the question.

A supplementary question, Mr. Speaker. As the minister plays his political football games with the provinces, who loses out are those young Canadians who are being cheated by this government's system on this particular issue.

April 29, 1992
Oral Questions
My question is quite simple. What will the minister do differently in order to address this concern, this national crisis, and eventually address the concerns of the prosperity agenda, global competitiveness and lead Canada out of educational and societal chaos?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not want to be too political, but that statement takes some gall.
It was his party that opposed in this House and in the other place a bill trying to target hundreds of millions of dollars to better train Canadian workers. It opposed it all the way.
Now he comes in this House and deplores the situation. What a bunch of-I will not say the word.
Oh, oh.

Mr. Speaker, he talks about global competitiveness. Welcome to the nineties. We are working with the private sector, and it will come up with an action plan that will hopefully address some of the problems that have been mentioned in this report. I think that Canadians will be all the better for it.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. We learned today that unemployment insurance benefits now cost us $4 billion. Last night, the Prime Minister spoke to people in the Outaouais and told them that they would lose their jobs if Quebec separated.
Instead of frightening people, would it not be better if the Prime Minister created jobs in Quebec and everywhere else? In that way, he would make a country where people would like to live.
Mr. Speaker, I may have missed the beginning of the hon. member's question, but I think that she is quite mistaken. I made no statement of that kind.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question.
I am not wrong in the fact that unemployment insurance payments have gone to $4 billion in Canada. What this government should be doing to add to the unity of this country is not to threaten job losses but to create jobs.
This government has choices. It has instruments in its power for positive change. As was mentioned, we now have an illiteracy rate in this country of 20 per cent and according to the Economic Council there is the possible creation of another million illiterate young people.
The government has cut $100 million from the job training funds. Will the Prime Minister recognize that unemployment costs this country money and costs this country in human potential. When will he put his government's resources into training to reduce illiteracy in this country and to creating jobs? That will bring the country together.

Mr. Speaker, it is always difficult to follow the socialists in their arguments. It is almost as hard as following the Liberals.
My hon. friend made two statements that I think she might want to re-examine. First of all, she said: "I think the unemployment insurance costs in Canada have gone to $4 billion". That is wrong. They have gone to $18 billion.
Second, she implied that I referred to that in my statement last night in Hull. I made no such statement at all, not directly or indirectly.
With regard to the separatists sitting back there, we will deal with them a little later. They are wondering about unemployment. The people who are going to be unemployed are those Bloc Quebecois separatist members sitting down there after the next federal election.

Mr. Speaker, in fact unemployment and social assistance cost this country $30 billion a year.
The financial costs, the human costs are huge. They are tragic and long term. I am saying to the Prime Minister, there are two ways we can go in building this country and making it stronger.
One is to threaten job loss, and the other is to make sure that we create jobs, have good training programs and have a fair tax system. With this government and its so-called tax reform those people making over $250,000
April 29, 1992

a year pay less taxes than they used to pay, but the unemployed still pay taxes on unemployment insurance.
When is the government going to make this country stronger, truly, by fair tax reform, creating jobs, attacking training and investing in Canadians, which is what the government should be doing?

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to dishearten my hon. friend, but she is wrong again in terms of her figures. The numbers are not the ones that she used.
If she would care to consult page 98 of the budget, she will see that the federal government does not transfer the amount to which she refers. We transfer $42.35 million in direct major transfers to persons, and we transfer in cash and tax transfers to other levels of government for that purpose an extra $38.9 billion, which indicates the enormity of the contribution of the Government of Canada toward the provinces for use in their jurisdiction.
My hon. friend is criticizing us for areas of jurisdiction that are exclusively provincial, for example education. We agree that education has to be improved, which is why there is the prosperity initiative. We do not have the right constitutionally to insinuate ourselves unilaterally into the jurisdictional areas of the provinces under the Constitution.
My hon. friend is concerned about the level of constitutional illiteracy in the House and so I am trying to deal with it. With regard to the report, I share my hon. friend's concern about some of the deficiencies in our system. But the report is useful in that it underlines the government's message that education and training are key to Canada's ability to compete internationally. The targets set out in the report are generally desirable and consistent with those mentioned in the Speech from the Throne.
In fact, to conclude, to indicate the advances that we are making, we actually heard from the Liberal Party today the word "competitiveness".

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of employment.
The minister claims that his government is committed to training. He claims that he has a modem and effective
Oral Questions
training and apprenticeship program. According to the Economic Council of Canada, today's apprenticeship programs produce a range of workers better suited for the job market in the 1940s, not the 1990s.
Will the minister of employment admit that his apprenticeship program is a failure, and when will he start doing something to help the hundreds of thousands of young people who need help to get a job?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, to continue the exercise of teaching constitutional law to the Liberals, apprenticeship programs are a provincial responsibility.
While apprenticeship is a provincial responsibility, the discussion paper entitled Learning Well-Living Well has outlined the major challenge which Canadians face in terms of having a better apprenticeship program.
I invite the Liberals to join with all other Canadians in trying to be part of the solution, not the problem.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is passing the buck. It seems to me that he is spending a little too much time under the sun.
I would like to ask the minister about his commitment to putting people back to work. He knows that the drop-out rate is 30 per cent in Canada, that 70 per cent of high school students do not attend post-secondary education. They need help in finding a job.
I would like to ask the minister specifically: What is he doing for the hundreds of thousands of young Canadians who leave high school and need help in finding a job? Specifically, what is he doing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know I must not do that too lightly, but whenever he refers to my colour in the sun in New Brunswick it is true that the republic of Madawaska has beautiful sun.

And where I come from, they know what I mean. [English]
As for the question the member raises, my colleague the minister for youth indicated yesterday that young Canadians looking for work benefit from programs for kids in schools, colleges and universities. For those youth who have quit school we have a host of programs trying

April 29, 1992
Oral Questions
to encourage them to improve their skills and knowledge in order to be able to get into the work force.
The hon. member would be well advised before criticizing Canada's youth to look at youth achievement-
I believe we must move on.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of employment.
The Economic Council of Canada report published today makes clear that this government is presiding over the development of a two-tier education system in Canada. One system, a slightly higher quality education system sustained by the richer provinces and another system, a lower quality education system barely sustained by the poorer provinces.
Does the minister think it is acceptable, coming from Atlantic Canada himself, that Atlantic Canadian students consistently demonstrate lower academic performance in the maths and the sciences and demonstrate a lower level of literacy in large part because of the $9 billion in education transfer cuts right across this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I know the hon. member would not want to induce anyone in error. When he refers to cuts, I challenge him to look at the figures for transfers to education in Atlantic Canada. I will bet-I will not do that; it is illegal.
Tomorrow it won't be.
I will not drive, either.
Oh, oh.

I will tell the hon. member that we are just as much concerned as we can be with the question of the level of education in Atlantic Canada, and for that matter in all of Canada.
When we consider that last year 300,000 jobs went unfilled in Canada because people did not have the
skills, we know we have a problem. That is why the prosperity initiative has produced a discussion paper where we invite all Canadians to be part of the solution.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister.
The minister knows the report today makes clear that Atlantic Canadians, when it comes to the quality of education they have access to, are fast becoming second-class citizens of this country.
In light of the clear evidence in this report, and I quote, "in light of the fact that provincial governments in Atlantic Canada are clearly struggling simply to maintain their educational system", what are this minister and this government going to do to restore access to all Canadians in every region to quality education?
Mr. Speaker, as a graduate of a maritime university I must take the responsibility-
Now we know what's wrong with you.
I want to point out for the House of Commons that a Liberal member of Parliament just said: "Now we know what's wrong with Canada".
I said you, not Canada.
This is a terrible statement for all of Atlantic Canada.
Shame, shame.
In fact this may break my hon. Liberal friend's heart, but Coline and I are graduates of the same university.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
In its swan song the Economic Council identified the fact that Canada is not number one in education or training.
What does the government plan to do about the fact that Canadian kids are not number one in preparation for entering school or leaving school, not number one in terms of vocational training, not number one in terms of numeracy, literacy or science skills, not number one with
April 29, 1992

respect to apprenticeship training availability or training availability, and that this country-
Perhaps there is a question there.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this rhetoric does not take away from the fact that the United Nations thinks we are number one on this planet.
In that report the hon. member will find another element that was contained in the Speech from the Throne of this government when we invited all Canadians, all stakeholders, to be part of the solution. That is what the prosperity initiative is all about, trying to invite Canadians to acknowledge the need to develop a training and learning culture in this country; not excluding anyone from the challenge but doing it together. That is what the prosperity-
We really do have to move on.

Mr. Speaker, the operative phrase in the question is: "What does the government plan to do?"
The council's report is a provocative indictment of the educational and training system of this country. It cries out for leadership and it cries out for action.
My question to the government side is: having killed the Science Council, having killed the Economic Council at this critical time, what action does the government plan to take in response to this report? What will it do to ensure that this country has the kind of policy analysis and research available to it to give leadership in education and training?

Mr. Speaker, I share any concern my hon. friend has about any deficiencies that do exist in our system. No one has ever said that Canada has a perfect educational system.
In fact one of the reasons why we were considering the possibility of trying to bring in national standards and so on was to enhance and strengthen the competitiveness of our educational system.
Pursuant to the objective criteria chosen by the United Nations a few days ago and announced a few days ago, Canada emerged further to an application of some important criteria as the number one nation in the world.
Oral Questions
That does not mean that Canada is a perfect nation, nor does it mean that we do not have difficulties. On the educational side because of the exclusive provincial jurisdiction that exists, there are inhibitions on the federal government and the Parliament of Canada in respect of any interventions that could be helpful. We have to try and bring the provinces along and persuade them even though this remains an area of exclusive provincial jurisdiction.
One thing we can do is, for example, to increase, as we have from $25.6 billion to $38.9 billion, our transfers to provinces in this general area to allow them to better help the citizens of their provinces enhance their skills and enhance their well-being. We are going to continue to do this, and I think my hon. friend would support us in that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the minister of employment. For months this government has been absolutely indifferent to the faltering economy of metro Toronto which traditionally has been one of the principal economic engines of this country.
Yesterday a metro government report concluded and found that 8,900 Toronto firms last year alone either moved out of the city or went bankrupt.
Therefore I ask the minister: When will his government recognize that the bankruptcy rate and the mass exodus of these Toronto firms are tied directly to this government's economic agenda? When can we expect a change of course in order to stimulate, redirect and turn around this very dangerous economic trend?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not want to be political, but when the member looks at the results in Toronto, I am tempted to ask what the previous provincial government and the current one have been doing about it.
He is not talking about the $350 million that we spent in downtown Toronto with de Havilland. He is not talking about the increase-I do not have the figure- the hundreds of millions more that we are going to be spending in Ontario, especially Toronto, on training.

April 29, 1992
Oral Questions
He wants to assign the blame for the global recession and the restructuring that has got to take place in the global economy to this government. Well, we are quite powerful. We have created a recession in the United States, in Japan, and in Germany. We are a powerful government. Thank you.

Mr. Speaker, my question is again for the minister of employment who I think is absolutely shocking and embarrassing in the face of the unemployment faced not only in Toronto but across the country for those kind of answers.
That same report found that the loss of those firms created a net loss of 65,000 jobs in Toronto alone and another 31,000 jobs were lost by the firms that remain because they downsized. What does this government have to tell those increasing numbers of unemployed Torontonians who are desperately searching for employment in a Toronto economy that is not only depressed, but shrinking?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member seems to picture us as taking pleasure at seeing people unemployed.
Canadians will look at the economic policy of this government. The interest rates we are experiencing today are a result of the deliberate policy of the government. The inflation rate at the lowest in 20 years is as a result of a deliberate policy. All of these policies will help create the climate that we need to create jobs for those people. We could go at it the Liberal way by the illusion of-
I think we will have to move on.

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the minister of employment.
A comprehensive economic review of the Hamilton labour market released at McMaster University concluded that while 36 per cent of employees felt they would be laid off this year, an astounding 52 per cent of business owners and managers said they will be laying off employees this year.
Given that alarming fact, what concrete action will the minister of employment take to ensure that employees in
Hamilton and in any other city across this great country will not become statistics?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what we will do for the people in Hamilton and everywhere in Canada is try to make these programs that are in place as helpful as they can be through the tough times that unemployed people have to go through.
We are spending this year in employment and immigration on the employment side $3.4 billion, which is $300 million more than last year, in trying to help those individual Canadians who are in this situation.
Of course, if the Liberal Party has any recommendation to make where we can improve what we are doing in this department in trying to help people without bankrupting Canada, I will listen to it.

Mr. Speaker, I have a suggestion for the minister of employment and it does not come just from the Liberal Party. It comes from those Hamiltonians who are out of work. Employed or not, 68 per cent of those surveyed would prefer retraining and work programs over UI and welfare.
Canadians want to go to work. They know that retraining by this government is the biggest myth being spread that we have ever heard by any government in this land.
Will the minister commit himself today to implement programs to get Canadians working again to ensure that those Canadians who do have jobs never have to fear for losing them?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member talks about training. We increased the level of dollars for training.
Over a two-year period, there has been a 120 per cent increase in funding for training unemployed Canadians. If my memory serves me well, they were in this House opposing this government and trying to block the amendment to the Unemployment Insurance Act that provides this money to needy Canadians. Now, the Liberals complain.
April 29, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the President of the Treasury Board.
The February 1991 budget outlined plans for eliminating layers of management in the government and eliminating at least 475 executive jobs, or 10 per cent. This was to be done over two years. Since over a year has passed, I would like to know what progress has been made.
Second, because the recession has been much worse than anyone anticipated, many large and small companies have had to take further tough steps to slash costs and cut more employees. In light of the long and brutal nature of this recession, is the Treasury Board planning even tougher measures to eliminate more management jobs in government?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)

Mr. Albert Cooper (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons) Mr. Speaker, I move that the 22nd report of the Standing Committee on House Management, presented to the House on Wednesday, February 12, 1992, be concurred in.
I do not want to take up too much time of the House but I do want to put on the record a few comments on this report.
Mr. Speaker, as you know, the issue of parliamentary reform and procedural reform has been an issue of members of Parliament and of this House for some time now, going back to the Lefebvre committee in 1982 or 1983, followed by the McGrath committee on reform and work that flowed out of that, which of course was very significant. It touched on a number of very important issues for members of Parliament, what we call private members, and an attempt by the McGrath committee to make certain that members of Parliament were active
Routine Proceedings
participants in the legislative process and were members who felt that they had a contribution to make and when they had an idea, they would then have an opportunity to pursue those goals and ambitions.
The McGrath task force focused on several things, but probably chief among those several items was the reform that was done to committees. It was a veiy significant change, a change that took committees from having to wait for a reference, largely from a minister or from a department to be able to do some work, to the point that we have committees today that are largely self-starting, self-motivating and have an ability to direct the areas and interests that they want to direct and to be able to put before this House some very important work.
I think for the most part that has been a very successful process, a process that I think all of us, as members of Parliament, are quite excited about. We certainly have some concerns about areas that we may want to see improvements in, but I think in general there is a strong feeling among members that the committees are better than they were prior to 1984. That is why so many of us put so much time into the work of those particular committees.
The report did other things, including changes to the Private Members' Business process, the election of the Speaker, making sure that once again there was an independence attached to the Chair and giving a sense of members of Parliament being very much involved in the process.
The 22nd report of the committee on House management is another report in the long evolution of reform of this institution. We have entered a new time frame or time period of coverage of the House of Commons. At one time it was all printed word. It was a few editors or writers sitting in the Press Gallery and reporting what was going on in Parliament.
This has now changed dramatically. It changed back in the late sixties when the cameras first came into the House of Commons. Suddenly, for the first time, Canadians were able to watch, via these television cameras, the debates in the House of Commons as they were happening. That was a major change.
It had a major impact on what happened to the institution. If we think back to why it was done, particularly in the style it was done, there was a great deal of concern by members of Parliament. They did not want it to become a show per se, they wanted the television

April 29, 1992
Routine Proceedings
cameras to be an electronic Hansard, a verbatim word for word picture of what is going on in the debates in this Chamber.
The management committee, recognizing the influence of television and recognizing the importance of it as a communication medium, recently put forward another report which was designed to open up the televising of the committees of the House of Commons. It will be an opportunity for Canadians to see where a good deal of the work of members of Parliament is done and let them see the environment in which those members are working. That was recently approved by the House.
The 22nd report, this report we are debating at this moment, is very much related to that subject. What we have asked in this 22nd report is that the cameras that focus on our debates during one time period of the day, Question Period, be allowed to change the coverage of this institution.
Right now we have the electronic Hansard format. The camera focuses on roughly my head and shoulders and that is the image that goes out across the country.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: CONCURRENCE IN 22ND REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE
speechtext: That is enough.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: CONCURRENCE IN 22ND REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE
speechtext:
Some would say that is enough but I can say at my particular height there is not a lot more.
We are proposing in this particular report that those camera angles be broadened a bit, not because of my height or my width but because we want to be able to give Canadians a context of what is going on. One of the things we have discovered in talking to people is that they find it very hard to relate to an individual face that seems to come out of nowhere and ask a question of somebody somewhere else, and that someone else is a head again answering. Canadians said no, wait a minute, we do not understand what is going on. We cannot put that in context.
This report is designed to allow us to open up a little bit so that the public will be able to see that if it is the hon. member for Cape Breton asking a question, he will be seen in the context of his colleagues. They will see the answer given to his question in the context of the cabinet members.
Then, Mr. Speaker, when you rise in your chair, they will see the cameras come back and see the Speaker in perspective with the whole House. In other words, the public will have a sense of both sides of the aisle. They will get an impression of where an hon. member is coming from and it will help them to understand the cut and thrust of the debate. They will see people on opposite sides of the House in most cases, as well as often opposite sides of the same issue, addressing one another in debate, which I think is an extremely important issue. The debate will make sense to people. They will begin to understand the relevance of these particular debates because right now they do not have an over-all picture. In fact, the impression could be that I am standing up to ask a question and my seatmate is going to stand up and answer it. They do not know where it is coming from. They have no sense of context.
Therefore, it is very straightforward. I want to emphasize that the committee agreed that this move should be experimental. I want to make that very clear for the record that this would be a 30 sitting day experiment. I am prepared to put that forward at this point in my remarks and to indicate that I am prepared to accept that suggestion from anyone on the other side of the House. It is designed to simply be an experiment.
We want Canadians to begin to understand this institution. This institution has not survived the televising of its debates very well. We believe that by allowing the public to see the questioners, to hear the answers in perspective, where everyone fits in the institution, what side of the House they are sitting on, where the Speaker sits in relation to the two sets of benches on either side of the aisle and what the Speaker is doing when, for example, there is disorder and noise and the Speaker is rising. But why is the Speaker rising?

subtopic: CONCURRENCE IN 22ND REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE
speechtext: Disorder is always on the government side.

subtopic: CONCURRENCE IN 22ND REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE
speechtext:
I am not here to debate which side is the guilty party. In fact, I would have to confess that both sides are guilty. Mr. Speaker, I know you do not see it that way, but I have to admit that from my humble perspective from time to time it is this side of the House that is causing the disorder.
April 29, 1992

Canadians will then see that. They will see you rising to bring order to the institution and they will see why you are rising because they can hear the noise and they can see what you are trying to accomplish.
I do not think there is anything sinister about this 22nd report. It is a very simple attempt on behalf of all members to adjust to the televising of one part of the debate called Question Period.
I want to emphasize that this is the work of the whole committee. It is a report that was adopted by the committee and recommended to this House. I know that the vast majority of my colleagues support it. When it went through the committee it was unanimous. I know there is significant support for it.
I would certainly encourage other members of this House to take a few minutes to recognize the fact that we are in a new age and that we have had to adjust. We are all doing it. I think this is one of the ways we can make that adjustment here in this Parliament, particularly for that one event called Question Period that gets so much of the television attention.
This will allow the Canadian public to put Question Period in context, in perspective. It will allow them to better understand the cut and thrust of debate in this House during Question Period, a debate all of us would argue is very, very important in terms of the issues across the land.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to intervene with regard to the motion of my colleague concerning the 22nd report of the House management committee.
The parliamentary secretary is somewhat selective in reviewing the process of this particular report and how it found itself in this Chamber today. I want to be clear so that the parliamentary secretary will have no doubt in his mind about where we stand with regard to the particular issue.

Concerning the wide angle camera shot, I was interested to hear the parliamentary secretary's new-found love for television and the televised proceedings of this Chamber.

It behoves me to underline the comment that some have made that perhaps the only reason we are proceeding with this particular change is that there may be a federal general election in the offing. Members of the government side who have been hiding behind ministers and in the backbenches would like to have a bit more exposure on television. That is one argument. I am sure other arguments would be made by other hon. members.
It is rather peculiar that the government and its representative, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Government House Leader, would now want to put in place wide angle camera shots of the Chamber. Mr. Speaker, perhaps you could share your great wisdom with us, but I do not know if the Chair has been consulted. I do not know if Mr. Speaker has been consulted on this particular manoeuvre.
I somehow doubt that Mr. Speaker has been consulted with regard to this matter unless it has been a private deliberation between the parliamentary secretary and Mr. Speaker. I do not know. You might wish to provide additional information later in the day concerning that particular item.
I find it passing strange that this has come up months before a federal election. All of a sudden, the televising of proceedings of the House of Commons has taken on a priority by the Government of Canada. One has to be, not cynical, but I would think just a smidgen suspicious as to why the government and the parliamentary secretary, who is a very able parliamentary secretary-I want to tell you that that parliamentary secretary will not remain a parliamentary secretary for a very long time and will probably aspire to other great things within the government.
I wish him well in his deliberations to try to put a manoeuvre to win support in the back benches so that other backbenchers will be able to obtain exposure on television for the purposes of election I think is going a bit far.
I would have thought that the campaign for bigger and greater things would have embarked upon a different course of action as opposed to trying to put forward this report No. 22 of the House management committee.
I wish to make this very clear to the hon. member. It is not the number of members of Parliament who are shown on television screen, whether it be the opposition side or the government side, that is the concern of

April 29, 1992

Canadians across this country. They do not care whether the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands on this side, or myself or my colleague for Ottawa-Vanier, or the parliamentary secretary and his colleagues, are on the television or not.
What Canadians are concerned with is the quality of the answers that are coming from the government with regard to important policy initiatives or lack of initiatives. That is the major concern of Canadians.
I have travelled this country extensively. I have never had a citizen of this great country come up to me and say: "You know, Mr. Dingwall, you have to get Albert Cooper on that television more often because I watch the proceedings of the House, and I think it is very important to have Mr. Cooper on television more often". I have never heard or come across a Canadian who has made that request of me as an opposition House leader. I have never met a Canadian who has come up to me and said that more Liberal members of Parliament have to appear on the television. It just does not happen.
What does happen is that Canadians want the government of the day-and it will be for a short period of time, I am sure it will not be for a very long period of time. This government is not going to be around for a long time-to provide quality answers. The New Brunswick shuffle that the Minister of Employment and Immigration did today with regard to important questions relating to unemployment insurance, training, apprenticeship, arid illiteracy did nothing to add to the confidence that Canadians have in this institution. Whether the minister is on television surrounded by two members of Parliament or 40 members of Parliament, or 100 members of Parliament, that is not the issue. The issue is the quality of the answers which ought to come from the government of the day.
Quite frankly, Canadians have told us, and my colleague from Ottawa-Vanier has said to me repeatedly that Canadians have written to him, they have written to me and my other colleague from Ottawa Centre where Parliament Hill is concerning not only the quality of the
answers, but also the action which is supposed to take place as a result of government initiatives.
We have seen that this government acts on very little. We could get into a very substantive debate. I see my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood who will probably want to enter this debate as well, but we could get into a very substantive debate on some of the major issues of the day.
Suffice it to say it is not the number of members of Parliament. It is not whether they are short, tall, whether they are as long or as wide as they are long, whether they have long hair or short haircuts like mine, or no hair like some other hon. members. That is not the issue. I have had numerous dealings with the parliamentary secretary, both in his senior capacity as parliamentary secretary and at another time on the energy committee, when he was in opposition and I was in government. I think I should rule on the amendment. I find nothing wrong with the amendment, but I do have trouble with the parliamentary suggestion that it is unusual for the House to amend a committee report. I would like to refer to Beauchesne's fourth edition, 1958, citation 323(2) which states:
A report in committee cannot be amended by the House, but it must be referred back to the committee.
Citation 322 states:
When the motion to concur is proposed the report may be referred back to the committee for further consideration or with instruction to amend it in any respect. It is not competent for a committee to reconsider and reverse its own decision, but if the House resolves that such reconsideration is necessaiy, the correct procedure is for the House to give the committee instructions which will enable it to consider the whole question again.
I think that is pretty clear. I regret that I cannot do anything more for the parliamentary secretary at this time, but I am sure that we will be able to resolve all our problems.

Once we start forgetting the rules, abandoning the procedures, then there is a disorderly situation which causes some problems for the House and for the people of Canada watching us.

Briefly this is that the House of Commons cannot amend a committee report. It has to send it back to that committee with a recommendation that an amendment be made and then it comes back here to be adopted.
We made that proposal today. We said that because the motion before us does not talk about certain things that we think have to be controlled by the Speaker, such as wide-angle shots, that the experiment have a time limit. We proposed 20 days. It sounds to me like a reasonable procedure. It is within the rules of this House to do that. It is the accepted procedure. It is backed up by Beauchesne. It is

backed up by all of the authorities that we have looked at. It is backed up by an awful lot of experience here. I think it is the way to proceed.
The other question of course is unanimous consent. Can one ask for unanimous consent on just about everything and anything? I submit to you very humbly, Mr. Speaker, that in my 19 years here if we accept this so-called myth that the House can do anything unanimously at any time, we are wrong, dead wrong. If you look at the jurisprudence, and I am going to quote from Beauchesne, Beauchesne makes a distinction between a substantive amendment, that is something that touches the essence or the principle of something, and a procedural amendment.
On procedure I have no difficulties. If unanimously today we decide to change a procedure, I say good. If we all agree, that is fine. But substantively, it cannot be done, unless notice is given to all members of Parliament, those who are not here, those who are in committee, those who are in their offices, those who are in their riding, that indeed the House is going to do something substantive. I think I am well supported on that argument by Beauchesne. I will quote from Beauchesne.

This is citation 18:
(2)	The House is perfectly able to give consent to set aside its Standing Orders and to give its unanimous consent to waive procedural requirements and precedents concerning notices and things of that sort.
I continue:
(3)	The extent of what may be done by unanimous consent is not clear, and Speakers have expressed doubts over the years when members attempted to introduce amendments contrary to the principle of a bill or requiring the Royal Recommendation. 19. Whenever the House proceeds by way of unanimous consent, that procedure does not constitute a precedent.

We cannot change the principle of a bill. If you cannot change the principle of a bill by unanimous consent, and that is substantive, why could you change a committee report which is substantive in itself by having the unanimous consent of those who happen to be here today? There might not be a member of that committee here today and we would change the way that committee operates. In 1977 the House adopted a motion to put television in this place and to give Canadians access through that media.
Many of us were concerned and worried that it would become show time. Many of us were concerned that it could be used to disadvantage some members. Our concerns were quietened by the fact that the Speaker, a very independent person, one we trust, would be responsible for the guidelines. There were other instances when television could not tell the whole story. When, for instance, the leader of my party, John Turner, announced his resignation, his family was in the galleiy. He wanted to recognize their presence. The cameras, however, could not show Mr. Turner's family being thanked by Mr. Turner. I thought that was rather unreasonable. I think sometimes we should show a little more sensitivity and consider the human aspect we would like Canadians to see when they watch the House of Commons.
When a newly elected member enters the House for the first time, the cameras are not allowed to cover the ceremony or to follow the member. I think that is a bit outdated. There are also unpleasant situations when a member is named and has to leave the floor of the House. Here again, the cameras are not allowed to focus on that person, because he or she does not have the floor.
When a member crosses the floor of the House, and there have been several instances, it is a traumatic experience. In some cases it is quite unpleasant, but these things happen. This is drama, but it is not shown on
April 29, 1992

This may be a new way to give Canadians a more comprehensive view of our proceedings, instead of the restrictive single image of our electronic Hansard.

We now have essentially an electronic Hansard. The member speaking is shown from the waist up, or less, or his or her face is shown, and that is it. When I lose the floor to somebody else the camera moves over to that person. The reaction time of the technicians upstairs makes some members on this side of the House uneasy.
It is important that we be seen on TV. It is important that we be seen actively engaged in debate. It is important to us in a political sense, in my political career as in everyone's. after the new-born or newly-adopted child arrives in the home.

Mr.Speaker, it is my pleasure and privilege tonight to speak on this most important and meaningful bill.
April 29, 1992

It is my firm belief that Remembrance Day, Canada's official day of mourning for her war dead, should be designated a holiday in the Public Service.
As Canadians, it is important that we recognize the contributions of those who fought for our country in these wars and that we realize the great sacrifices that these men and women gave for their country, indeed, the ultimate sacrifice on many occasions.
I urge all members of Parliament from all parties to recognize November 11. It deserves the utmost reverence by the Government of Canada. There are many things that can be said about those who served their country in war and many phrases that can be bestowed upon them.
Tonight I would like to say a few words in the hope that we can come to a better understanding and appreciation of what we have accomplished as a nation, thanks to those who served and in some cases died for their country. They did it for Canada and they did it for us. We should never be allowed to forget that.
Between 1914 and 1918, Canada sent some 625,000 men to the battlefields of Europe. For a nation of only eight million people, this was a tremendous contribution. More than 60,000 of these Canadians never returned and thousands more were maimed and disabled.
When Britain declared war, Canada as a British colony entered the war automatically. Canada was not prepared at that time. It was ill-equipped and had a permanent army of only 3,000 men who were inadequately trained. Increasingly Canadian soldiers played an active role in the war front as they became more effective soldiers.
By the end of the war, Canadians and Canada as a country and as a nation had gained a new confidence and a new reputation around the world. In fact Canada had become an integral part of the war effort. We paid and paid dearly. The price was losing a generation of young Canadians and the sheer horror of the war faced by these Canadians.
One Canadian soldier remembers the Germans' use of poison gas in April of 1915.1 would like to read from his account. He says:
Private Members' Business
I saw the whole picture of the gas attack probably like no one else did. I had never been in battle-and I have been in many-where the men were suffering in such numbers that their crying and groaning could be heard all over the battlefield. There were some who ran away. These were individuals. They were young and they were terrified. They had never seen gas before. None of us had - it was the first gas attack in history. But not a single unit skipped out-some individuals, yes, but formations, no. Suddenly, we saw the gas rolling up in a brownish-yellowish bank. It was between four and twelve feet high and it wouldn't rise higher unless it was puffed up by the wind. I went over to where the line had been broken and where there was confusion. No Canadian troops were running. The gas was dreadful and suffering was immediate. The only thing we could do was to soak our handkerchiefs in urine and hold them up over our noses. Thousands were lying around gasping and crying. They were being drowned by gas. They didn't know how to protect themselves. But we held our position.
In April of 1917, 70,000 Canadian soldiers fought in the battle of Vimy Ridge. On April 9 the offensive began. Within hours, Canadian soldiers pushed back the enemy and captured the ridge. But the cost was high; indeed the cost was high for all Canadians; more than 10,000 casualties, including some 3,000 dead.
Another soldier tells his story:
Easter Sunday, the eve of the battle, was fine and sunny. All was peaceful to the eye, as unit by unit took its way in ordered leisure up the slopes and spurs. Wonderful in their work in secrecy had been the engineers. For months they delved underground. The tunnel system ran sheer into and up the ridge, to open at the very feet of the Germans. Through these subways, passes every man of the tens of thousands who played a part in the battle. Sleep, in the rare moments, throughout the hectic week was so only if one stood flat against the wall. Our barrage which opened at 5.30 a.m. involved a gun to every 25 yards and was as regular as a clock. Nothing human could stand against it. So, from Monday's dawn till midnight of Friday the battle raged. But we were masters of our fate, filthy but triumphant and had scored a signal victory as has ever crowned Canadian arms.
Another soldier remembers.
I was wounded and went back, and there was a great crowd of people when the ship came in. All of a sudden somebody says this, "The Canadians. They've taken Vimy. Nobody did it before." And what a cheer went up. They threw chocolate bars. They threw flowers. In fact, I broke down and cried. We achieved something that nobody had done before. I think myself, that was where Canada was bom.
Indeed, Canada emerged from the war well on its way to nationhood, earning the praise, the respect and the admiration of its allies. This is the moment that Canada came of age as a nation. For the thousands who fought and gave their lives in the war, in the "war to end all wars", we must never forget.

April 29, 1992
