In September 1939 Canada declared war on Germany. It was the first time in its history that Canada as an independent country and not a colony had entered a war. But like the First World War, Canada was militarily unprepared. Numbers were small and the army was badly equipped. Yet by the end of the war, Canada was described as having one of the best armies in the world and again as in the great war our soldiers fought with distinction. The assault on Normandy on D-Day was typical of the many landings on the beaches of that time. Another account:
All the boats were under criss-cross machine gun fire. As the first men jumped they crumpled and flopped into the water. Then order was lost. It seemed to the men that the only way to get ashore was to dive head first in and swim clear of the fire that was striking the boats. But, as they hit the water, their heavy equipment dragged them down and soon they were struggling to keep afloat. Some were hit in the water and wounded. Some drowned then and there. But some moved safely through the bullet fire to the sand, finding that they could not hold there, went back into the water and used it as a cover, only their heads sticking out. Those who survived kept moving forward with the tide, sheltering at times behind underwater obstacles and in this way, they finally made their landings. Within ten minutes of the ramp being lowered, 'A" company had become inert, leaderless and almost incapable of action. Every officer and sergeant had been either killed or wounded. It had become a struggle for survival and rescue. The men in the water pushed wounded men ashore ahead of them and those who had reached the sands crawled back into the water pulling others to land to save them from drowning, in many cases only to see the rescued men wounded again or to be hit themselves.
The Korean conflict in 1950 saw Canada rally to the support of the United Nations. Of 8,000 Canadians who fought in Korea, 406 lost their lives while another 1,200 were injured. Again, Canadians played an integral part in the war effort and many died serving their country.
As Canadians, we must always remember the incredible sacrifices that thousands upon thousands of Canadians were willing to make for this country, Canada, the country that they loved so much. We must realize why they were willing to make these sacrifices.
The Government of Canada has an obligation to reaffirm its commitment to remembrance because as Canadians, we must never forget or to let other Canadians forget. We must not forget that people from across this great nation took action and acted as one. Their contribution was unified and they unified the country.
That geographically at the time made no sense for many Canadians. This was the first time they saw themselves as a part of a larger Canada and what they, as a nation, could accomplish as one.
We are not here to glorify war. We are here simply to remember. We are here to thank all the men and women who served Canada in its time of war. We owe them all an eternal debt which we must not forget.

Mr. Speaker, it is with some surprise actually that I am rising today to speak to this bill.
I have always assumed that Remembrance Day was a special day in this country, a day on which we would observe and remember those who have fought in past wars for Canada and those who have given the ultimate sacrifice for this country.
I was actually surprised to learn that this day, Remembrance Day, is now considered to be a bargaining chip to be used by governments in negotiating contracts. In fact I find that hard to believe.
Remembrance Day is now listed in the so-called Holidays Act, but looking further one realizes that this does not give any sort of guarantee that it will remain a special day for Canadians, a day on which workers in this country can take the time to remember.
I find it very disconcerting that we now can use this day as a bargaining tool in which to give or take away certain rights in a labour contract. It seems quite disrespectful, I would suggest, to the veterans of this country and to those who, as I have said, have given the ultimate sacrifice.
I believe there have been some conflicts for the past while, but it was Canada Past last year that threw it on the table as a bargaining chip. I must commend the member for Dartmouth for raising this matter and for bringing this bill to the House.
It is very important that Remembrance Day does not diminish in this country. In fact unfortunately in many ways, it is diminishing. As time goes on, we recognize Remembrance Day less and less. I remember when I was a young boy in Moose Jaw, there was a whole host of events surrounding Remembrance Day. For weeks leading up to Remembrance Day there were numerous events taking place. Remembrance Day was a special day. It was a day when you went to the cenotaph in your
April 29, 1992

particular community and the ceremonies that took place.
There is some concern that as we move further and further away, as veterans get older and die that the day becomes less important. By taking this day we want to make sure that it will remain as a day of remembrance and not a holiday at some other time of the year or to be bargained off by the government for extra pension benefits or whatever the situation may be, that it is instilled in statute that we will remember this day.
Certainly we can do no less for the veterans of this country, particularly in light of the fact that we are making so much of the battles that have taken place. The 50th anniversary of Dieppe is coming up and so on.
I know that it is of concern to veterans in my riding. I have received letters from the Royal Canadian Legion in Lanigan which sent me a letter. I received a letter and petition from Laurie Mang who is with the Army, Navy, Air Force Veterans in the city of Moose Jaw, along with something like 15 names on a petition. Unfortunately, it is a petition I cannot introduce in the House because it is not in the proper form.
I also received another letter from the Royal Canadian Legion in Moose Jaw, again with another petition with something like 120 names. These people are concerned and are surprised that the government may in fact not be willing pass this piece of legislation.
Their sentiments were summed up quite nicely by the Dominion President of the Royal Canadian Legion who wrote a letter to the Prime Minister on April 2 out of concern for this bill. I am just going to read part of that letter for the benefit of those Canadians watching.
In part he writes: "Apparently the Treasury Board has reservations regarding the impact this legislation could have on future collective bargaining with Public Service unions. The Treasury Board seems to believe that entrenching Remembrance Day in this act would be tantamount to discarding a bargaining chip or potentially negotiable benefit".
He goes on to say that a great deal of confusion exists as to the actual status of Remembrance Day and this bill would go a long way toward dispelling the notion that
Private Members' Business
November 11, Canada's official day of mourning for her war dead, is a holiday. In fact, passage of this bill would reaffirm the Government of Canada's commitment to remembrance.
He continues by saying: "The Legion considers it entirely inappropriate that a bill dealing with remembrance is apparently being judged solely on the basis of several ill-defined and questionable fiscal points raised by Treasury Board. There is no doubt that a great many of the 600,000 Legion members and affiliates will not appreciate any decision on this bill which fails to acknowledge the importance of perpetuating the tradition of remembrance. Prime Minister, I sincerely request that you reconsider your position vis-a-vis this most important, symbolic piece of legislation". This is signed by J.W. Jolleys, the Dominion President.
As I said, I find it somewhat extraordinary that we are debating this bill. In fact, I am surprised that we are simply not recognizing the fact that the member for Dartmouth brought this to the attention of the House, put the bill forward and that we are not unanimously passing this bill. I do hope that enough members of the government side will find it appropriate to support this legislation.
Surely the idea of a cost should not really be a consideration. The fact is that it is already a holiday for the Public Service sector and it already exists. It is not a cost that is going to be added to the budget, it is already there.
What we are simply saying is let us make sure that this bill stays there. Let us make sure that this day retains the status that it does even if in other sectors of our country the importance of Remembrance Day diminishes in some areas, which it is going to over time.
Certainly this Parliament owes it to the veterans of this country to ensure that it does not happen in the public sector, that it does not happen in the federal sector and that we set an example for all this country to ensure that we retain the importance of this day and that it remains a day that it was meant to represent. That is the fact that November 11 was of special significance. As Canadians will know, it was the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918 that the war to end all wars, as they say, ceased. So November 11 is the day that we should

April 29, 1992
Private Members' Business
recognize and remember as we do now every November 11 at the 11th hour of that 11th day.
I want to conclude by saying that it is only proper, respectful and fitting that we support this bill in recognition of those veterans and of those Canadians who have made the ultimate sacrifice and in fact those who fought in those wars as well because they sacrificed as well. I would be shocked, as I know most Canadians would be shocked, if this bill fails to pass.
I urge all members to give due consideration to this bill and look within their hearts and their conscience and I am sure they will pass this bill.

Mr. Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to say a few words with respect to Bill C-289 which, as you know, is an act to provide that Remembrance Day be included as a holiday in Public Service collective agreements, that in fact every collective agreement entered into pursuant to the Public Service Staff Relations Act should provide for Remembrance Day to be a holiday.
Mr. Speaker, as you so very well know, for veterans, their families, and I include myself in that, and their friends, Remembrance Day is in fact the most solemn and the most sacred day of the year. It was in fact on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month that World War I came to an end and it is that day that has been designated ever since as Remembrance Day. It is a day to be enormously thankful and grateful to all those who served in a variety of wars on behalf of Canada and many of whom paid the supreme sacrifice.
In particular on Remembrance Day in recent years we have paid tribute to and remember those who served and those who died in World War I, in World War II and in Korea, but for many many Canadians that day, that time and that moment is also a day to reflect on relatives who served in years gone by in wars and in battles in which Canada served many many years ago. For instance, a cousin of mine, Bertha Redway's father Edgar, served in the Boer War on behalf of Canada. There are many families who still proudly claim to have relatives who served in that war on behalf of this country.
As well, there are all those who served in Canadian peacekeeping forces whether it be on Cyprus or in the
Middle East or now in what used to be Yugoslavia, all of those Canadians we think of and remember on this very special day.
Each person who celebrates that day, each person who participates in that day has their own very special thoughts that come flooding back to them.
In my own case, the day that stands out the most in my memory is D-Day. That was the day my father's regiment, the Queen's own Rifles of Canada, went ashore on the beachhead at Berniere sur Mer. Within a few short hours young men, mere boys many of them, who had trained together and served together for many years in Canada and Great Britain, and then finally went ashore that morning seeing action for the first time were almost eliminated.
Company A and Company B of the Queen's own Rifles of Canada lead by the two Dalton brothers, Elliot and Charlie Dalton, both of whom were severely wounded in that action, were virtually annihilated that day in but a few short hours.
I have had the great privilege of remembering that day on two occasions now, on my own cable television program with two of my constituents, veterans of the Queen's own Rifles Regiment that went ashore that day, John Hadley and Rolf Jackson, one of whom interestingly and strangely enough is the brother-in-law of our own good colleague in this House the member for Erie, Girve Fretz. Both of them went ashore that morning with the Queen's own Rifles. Both were wounded in action. For both the war was very short.
I have other special thoughts as well that come to mind on Remembrance Day. Others in my family, my uncle, retired Colonel Frank Klenavic, who served with the RCR, the Royal Canadian Regiment, in Sicily, Italy, and northwest Europe. He later commanded the regiment in the Korean campaign.
I think as well of my former law partner, Sydney Frost, now a retired colonel who served with the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry, the PPCLI, in Italy and Holland. He was severely wounded twice in the head. He is lucky to be alive. He recovered enough to go back into battle and was wounded again. Later in civilian life he commanded the militia regiment, the Royal Regiment of Canada which as you know, Mr. Speaker, went ashore at Dieppe.
April 29, 1992

The Royal Regiment too was decimated in that action at Dieppe. I think of many good friends who were law clients of mine who served with the Royal Regiment, went into Dieppe and later became prisoners of war and spent most of the rest of the war after 1942 as prisoners of war.
I think as well of other good friends, for example, Keith Knowles with the Irish Regiment of Canada who served in Italy and northwest Europe.
I could go on and on reciting the names and deeds of friends and relatives I think of myself each Remembrance Day. I am sure that all members of this House have thoughts of friends and relatives.
It is a time when we remember. It is a time when we become quite emotional if we had some personal connection with one of those wars or some of those battles. Fortunately or unfortunately, I am not sure what is the right word, there are now fewer and fewer of us who have some sort of personal memories of those events.
I know when World War II ended I was a mere 10 years old. I remember VE Day quite vividly. I remember VJ Day quite vividly. These are days that stand out. They are days that will always stand out in my memory.
We are now at a stage where the average age of a Korean war veteran, not the peacekeepers who have followed, but the Korean war veterans who fought in that war, Canadians, is now around 65 years of age. We are getting to a time when it is very difficult to find people, there are fewer and fewer people, who actually have personal memories about what went on.
I guess it is most important that somehow we strive to perpetuate this remembrance and this act of understanding of the sacrifices that were made for you and me and for all Canadians.
These days it is often done in school assemblies. It is not usually a holiday for the schools in my community. They honour the day with a special assembly, and they pay tribute to the events and the sacrifices.
Department stores often honour the day with a moment of silence. Everything comes to a standstill. Everyone in fact stands still, bows his or her head and recognizes that moment of silence.
Private Members' Business
There are, of course, municipal ceremonies of remembrance. There are church services, Legion services. My own Legion branch, Branch 10 of the Royal Canadian Legion, one of the oldest branches of the Legion has a Remembrance Day service the Sunday before November 11, each and every year. In fact, it has the longest continuous Remembrance Day service of any branch of the Legion in this country.
There used to be a day when it seemed to me at least that we celebrated Remembrance Day with a universal holiday, but we got away from that fact perhaps because there are fewer people with personal memories. It is perhaps because many people treat it as a holiday and do not really remember.
That is what we have to decide in this debate. What is the best way to perpetuate and symbolize Remembrance Day? Perhaps it is with a holiday, but surely not just a holiday for a portion of Canadians. If we are going to celebrate it with a holiday, surely, it should be a statutory holiday for all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, it is indeed a privilege and an honour for me to speak on Bill C-289 as it is also my belief and my wish that this private member's bill presented to the House by my colleague from Dartmouth becomes law.
Bill C-289 is an act to provide for Remembrance Day to be included as a holiday in Public Service collective agreements.
Since observing Remembrance Day in years 1990 and 1991, the world has moved forward at an astonishing pace. The gulf war ended with Kuwait free once more. Our Canadian forces returned home to the kind of victorious welcome given to our returning troops 47 years ago.
Dramatic changes are sweeping the Soviet Union where the people are insisting on the kind of democracy we defended half a century ago. Today, Yugoslavia and Afghanistan are tormented by the ravages of war.
I wonder, as we speak to this bill that would further honour Remembrance Day, how it might have been had reporters carried today's sophisticated equipment with them in Hong Kong, Kapyong, Dieppe, Ortona or Vimy Ridge. Would we better appreciate the terrible cost of freedom had Canadians seen those battles taking place? Would we have a better understanding of the value of our own country and the awful sacrifices we have made in its name? Would we then not be entirely resolute in

April 29, 1992
Private Members' Business
our determination to keep our wonderful country together?
On November 11 of every year we should all be permitted to take the time to remember those who fought and those who died for our freedom and to pledge at the same time that their valiant efforts will not have been in vain. They fought and often died for a proud, united and prosperous Canada.
Since the bill was introduced last fall I have received letters, telephone calls and comments from a number of constituents. The Royal Canadian Legion Branch 85 of Kapuskasing sent me a letter on April 20, 1992. Please allow me to quote from it as I believe the House will find it interesting:
This is to inform you that we at the Branch 85 of the Royal Canadian Legion in Kapuskasing support keeping Bill C-288 the Act of Remembrance Day, alive. We hope that during the third reading of the bill at the end of this month you will voice our concerns in favour of Bill C-289. As Legionnaires it is important that we keep Remembrance Day alive for those who fought and died for us as well as the many families who have been left behind.
The letter was signed by Pat Green, president of the branch. It summarizes more than adequately the true significant of Remembrance Day.
I must reiterate that I am proud of this bill. I am also proud of my constituents in the Royal Canadian Legion of Canada. They have expressed the same concerns toward Bill C-289 as did the huge majority of Canadians and 700,000 Legionnaires across Canada.
Remembrance Day should not be a negotiable item or a bargaining chip for anyone, including the Public Service, negotiating a collective agreement. I even find it distressing that it was used two years ago in negotiations between Canada Post and one of its unions.
Out of respect for those who have served and even shed their blood for us, Remembrance Day should be a special day as are Confederation Day, Labour Day and Thanksgiving.
Bill C-289 should not only be passed to include Remembrance Day as a holiday for the public servants. It should also be extended to the elementary and secondary schools of our country. These students, young and old, should be made aware of not only the horrors of war, but
they should also fully recognize and appreciate the immeasurable value of living in a free country.
This is where the education process should begin and should be permeated. Our young Canadians are being exposed to Remembrance Day via television in the news or at a ceremony at school, but they do not have the opportunity to witness the real ceremony at the cenotaph. This is where veterans are solemnly assembled to reflect on the awful consequences of war, of colleagues and friends who have either died or were seriously wounded in the name of freedom. Our young people want to know all about Remembrance Day and we should ensure their need is fulfilled.
This could only be accomplished with the full co-operation of both senior levels of government, and we in this House should be the leaders.
The adoption of this bill goes beyond partisanship that is often displayed in this House. I therefore urge all of my colleagues to set aside party lines and vote unanimously to recognize the contribution of those who have served in the Canadian Armed Forces.
I strongly believe this bill is the only way to ensure that Remembrance Day remains first in our minds and hearts on November 11. This is how it should be. Let us not forget.

Mr. Speaker, just a few short weeks ago we commemorated the battle of Vimy Ridge. Our Prime Minister and a parliamentary delegation went to France to participate in the commemoration of a battle that some have said was the coming of age of Canada. It may have been that, but it certainly was a demonstration to the world that this young, tiny, underpopulated country could act with heroism, with great skill, to fulfil its international responsibilities. That is something we have been doing for many decades now.
It is only a few short steps from Parliament Hill to the National War Memorial where every year now for over 70 years at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month our Prime Minister, international dignitaries and representatives of virtually every sector of our Canadian community gather to pay tribute and to remember those who fought for all of us so that we would still have the democratic institutions we are privileged to serve in this Parliament.
April 29, 1992

Private Members' Business
It was in this Parliament over 70 years ago now that that day was declared to be Armistice Day and to be kept in remembrance of those who had served and died in the First World War. It was changed to Remembrance Day in 1931. When I was a little girl it was still Armistice Day; that is what we called it. It is deeply troubling that there is even some thought that we should not take one small step to entrench this day permanently in our history as a day of remembrance.
We have to remember that it is only short weeks ago that volunteers for the Korean war were finally recognized for their service with the Korean Volunteer Medal. It is very recently that the contribution of merchant marines in the Second World War has been recognized in any way.
I am very proud of the 480 Westboro Branch of the Royal Canadian Legion in my riding. It has started in recent years a tradition that I hope will grow and spread. Westboro Branch constructed its own war memorial. For the last two years it has remembered those who have served this country so well, not just one day a year, but on the anniversary of every major battle.
Why we need to remember is because, as my colleague speaking before me has so admirably said, those who have a direct personal connection with the veterans are growing fewer and fewer. The veterans themselves are growing fewer and fewer. We see them year after year in smaller numbers still suffering, still carrying the scars of the sacrifice they made for all of us.
There are others who suffered as well. So we have the Silver Cross Mother every year at the War Memorial representing those family members who also suffered and were part of that sacrifice. This year Mrs. Alice Taylor from Ottawa West was Canada's Silver Cross Mother. She is very proud of that and I am very proud of her.
Remembering is more than simply remembering the veterans. That alone is important and that alone is valuable. Why we remember and the other things that we are reminded of in remembering them are also important. We remember what the best of human valour and achievement can be when we remember those veterans because they made the ultimate sacrifice of risking and often giving their lives for others. There is no braver thing that a human being can do.
We also remember and value the democracy they fought for. We cannot have Remembrance Day and take for granted the privileges of being a democracy. We also remember that war is not a glamorous thing and that peace is something to be sought in their memory.
I go to the Westboro Legion to attend its remembrance services several times a year. The ceremony always closes with these words, which typify what this motion is all about, which is to ensure that at least for one segment, those who work for this Parliament in delivering services to Canada, this day shall be sacred as a holiday in perpetuity.
I close as the remembrance services at my Legion close, with these words: "We will remember them, we will remember them".

speakeroldname: Mr. Marcel R. Tremblay (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Dartmouth has proposed a private member's bill, Bill C-289, an act to provide that Remembrance Day be included as a holiday in Public Service collective agreements.
Under this bill, every collective agreement entered into pursuant to the Public Service Staff Relations Act shall provide: (a) that Remembrance Day is to be a holiday; (b) that no employee in a bargaining unit shall be required to work on Remembrance Day unless it is essential for the public safety or public interest that the work be done on that day; (c) that an employee who is required to work on Remembrance Day shall receive an extra remuneration or benefit for doing so.
I wish to say unequivocally that my opposition to the hon. member's proposal is in no way directed at the obvious sincerity of his effort to highlight the importance of Remembrance Day. Nevertheless, I must emphasize that I am not at all persuaded that the proposal put forward will have the desired effect.
The federal government negotiates under the Public Service Staff Relations Act with 80 bargaining units, 17 different unions, some 187,000 unionized employees and 23,000 non-union employees. Thanks in large part to the collective bargaining process, these employees already

April 29, 1992
Private Members' Business
have a provision in their collective agreements that designates Remembrance Day as a paid holiday.
Once a benefit is covered in a law, it is no longer negotiable, for all practical purposes. If practices change or the need for a particular benefit increases or decreases, the only way to change it would be through legislation.
This bill does not meet the concerns of the members who spoke in favour of the bill in the House in that it does not help people better understand the meaning of Remembrance Day or make them aware of it. It only confirms a holiday that is already granted to public servants.
I do not believe that the holiday that federal government employees and many other workers would have confers particular importance on commemorating those who served their country or gave their life to it. For example, schools hold ceremonies in which all students take part and during which they hear about the selfless deeds done by their heroes and the debt that we can never repay them.
In my opinion, remembering what they did and not the holiday makes that day special in our eyes. This is a question on which it is very hard not to agree because hon. members may think that I am against Remembrance Day, when in fact I am talking about the need to leave it to the collective bargaining process rather than to impose a decision by legislation.
In conclusion, I agree with having all Canadians remember our heroes' valour and the importance of Remembrance Day. Nevertheless, I must conclude that the proposal of the hon. member for Dartmouth does nothing to achieve that objective.

Mr. Speaker, I fully endorsed this bill in the previous sitting. I know that all members of the Legion in my riding who have come to me in support of this bill would understand that rather than continuing with my speech I would defer to my colleague from London East who was detained earlier but is now in the House and is now able to add his
voice to the long list of members who support our colleague from Dartmouth.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I am just looking at the record and must say that the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood spoke on this bill in the first 60 minutes. Therefore, I would like to recognize the hon. member for London East.

Mr. Speaker, my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood obviously wants to speak as much as possible on this bill because he believes in this bill, as I do, and as does my colleague from Dartmouth who has proposed this very important bill, Bill C-289. It really is an honour and a privilege for me to stand before this House in support of this private members' bill that will go a long way toward ensuring that Remembrance Day is embedded in collective agreements and is fully recognized as a holiday, and is not in legislation which can be removed at any future date.
Of course it should not be used as a bargaining chip. The President of the Treasury Board has now indicated that he cannot support this private member's bill because it would take away some flexibility from the Treasury Board in future negotiations with the Public Service.
That is a red herring in this whole argument. My colleague from Dartmouth has essentially put it in its proper context. This bill is not only important to the veterans of this country and the Legionnaires across this country who, let us not forget, have given up and sacrificed much for this country.
On our 125th birthday this year nothing would be more fitting than a tribute to those veterans who have given up so much, to their families who have sacrificed so much, to finally recognize without any question that Remembrance Day should be recognized for what it is. It is Canada's day to display its respect for our veterans and an indication of how much we appreciate what they have done for this country.
Bill C-289 essentially tries to take any ambiguity out of the future of this holiday as we have come to know and respect it for the past number of years and to put it in the collective agreements to ensure that it cannot be tampered with. For the government to even suggest that it wants to use it and that it would take away from its flexibility is an insult to this country, to every veteran in
April 29, 1992

this country, their families and the veterans who died for this country. It is a slap in the face to them.
The fact that this government has put up this red herring and has instructed its government benches to vote against this private members' bill is absolutely uncalled for and disgraceful. In fact, the Dominion president, Mr. Jolleys, wrote to the Prime Minister on April 2 when Legion members across the country became aware of this government's hesitation in supporting Bill C-289.
In fact, he wrote to the Prime Minister indicating how outraged the Legions and their members across this country were at the fact that Treasury Board would even consider this to be a bargaining chip to be used at its whim in order to achieve certain things with the Public Service.
Let us remember November 11 for what it is, that is to remember the contribution of veterans across this country. That is what this bill seeks to do. Playing politics with such a bill, I suggest as I have before, shows absolutely no respect whatsoever for the meaning of that day in Canada's history nor shows little more respect for the veterans who this bill wants to pay tribute to.
Again, I want to convey to this House that in fact the member for Dartmouth, after a considerable amount of work, diligence and consultation, managed to put forward this bill that in fact has all the support of 650,000 Legion members across this country and seeks again to take away any ambiguity presently under the Holidays Act in which November 11 is stated to be a holiday.
I do not think at this point on this particular issue that we should at all play politics with it. I would urge and hope that the government members see this bill for what it is. There are other ways, of course, in terms of negotiating with the Public Service rather than trying to take away the most symbolic and most important of holidays, that is November 11, Remembrance Day.
I would hope that the Prime Minister would heed the letter of the Dominion president and would essentially let the members of the government backbenches vote as their conscience would dictate so that in fact they can show that this House unanimously supports the veterans of this country and that, without question, we would want to ensure that November 11 is recognized for what
Private Members' Business
it is, a holiday in remembrance of veterans and what they have done for this great country.
It seems to me that if, in fact, the government did not see this as a threat to its authority, that it would not take away any flexibility in dealing with the Public Service, surely to God it would not want to use such an instrument as Remembrance Day to be able to do something with respect to the Public Service.
Who would you hurt by in fact turning down this bill? You would not be hurting the Public Service. You would be hurting the veterans. You would be hurting those people who have sacrificed much for this country. Let us not lose sight of what my hon. colleague from Dartmouth has tried to achieve, a bill that once and for all without question recognized the great contribution of veterans across this country to put into those agreements November 11 as a holiday for Canadians to recognize what Remembrance Day is about.
I am sure that each and every November 11, Mr. Speaker, you stand among many across this country in front of a cenotaph. We are there to pay tribute to those men and women who have fallen and to those men and women who have given much to this country. They have sacrificed much.
It would seem to me that this House, through this bill, would be sending a signal to our young people, to all people, that Remembrance Day should not be forgotten but should be remembered more so so that this country would not have to go through the sacrifices that it has in the past.
It is for peace. It is to recognize the great sacrifices that the men and women have made for this great country. Anything that this House can do from an educational standpoint to instil in young people, in all people, the great importance of Remembrance Day is what we should do. I think this bill does that.
Now that it is before us, if this government plays politics with it and turns it down, what kind of a signal would we be sending not only to the veterans?
What kind of signal would we be sending to those young people and other people across Canada who want to pay tribute to the veterans? We would not just be slapping veterans in the face but we would be saying to the rest of the country: "I guess November 11 does not really have any meaning because we are prepared to turn down a bill that without question would firmly put this in legislation and also in every agreement so that it cannot

April 29, 1992
Private Members' Business
be tampered with". This is one day that should be and will be remembered forever.
In conclusion, let us not forget that this bill is for recognition for the veterans. We do not want to play politics with that particular day and this private member's bill as proposed by the member for Dartmouth will essentially make that a reality.
Again, if the government feels threatened because this might take away some bargaining chip or some flexibility in its future negotiations with the Public Service, there are other ways of dealing with the Public Service in a constructive manner rather than holding such a constructive bill over the heads of the Public Service and saying that is why we cannot support it for the veterans.
I am proud to stand and support this bill. As my colleague from Dartmouth has said in his bill, it is finally recognizing, without question, the great contribution of the veterans of this country.
